dialogue.content: I see. How about washing dishes? Do you find it difficult to manage with your current level of pain and stiffness?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, that's been one of my biggest challenges lately. The water temperature makes my hands ache, and trying to grip the dish sponge is really hard. It takes me so long to do something as simple as washing a few dishes.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That must be frustrating. Have you noticed any particular tasks or activities that make your symptoms worse? For example, using electronic devices or playing sports?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Actually, yes. Using my phone can be quite uncomfortable for me right now. The screen feels too sensitive to touch, and I have trouble holding it up to read messages. And as for sports, I loved playing basketball before the RA set in, but even just dribbling a ball is really hard on my hands now.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That's understandable. How about reaching or stretching? Do you find yourself having to adjust your movements or avoid certain activities because of pain or stiffness?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, definitely. Even everyday tasks like folding laundry or reaching for something in a high cabinet can be painful if I'm not careful. I try to pace myself and avoid overexerting my arms.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: How do you feel about the progress you've made so far? Are there any positive changes that stand out to you?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Honestly, it's hard to see right now because of how unpredictable this condition is. But I have been getting better at recognizing my limits and taking breaks when I need them. That feels like a small victory.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That's great! It sounds like setting realistic goals for yourself might be helping you stay motivated. Have you noticed any emotional changes or challenges related to your RA? For example, feeling anxious or frustrated because of the limitations it imposes on your daily life?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, definitely. Some days I feel really down about it, especially when I'm not able to do things with my friends and family like we used to. It's hard to accept that my body isn't what it used to be. But talking to them about how I'm feeling has helped a lot.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Hi, how are you doing today?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: I'm okay, a bit tired. Had a long day yesterday with classes and work.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That sounds exhausting. Hopefully, today will be more relaxing. What did you do last night to unwind?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Just watched a movie at home. Nothing too strenuous.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That's nice. Did anything in particular catch your eye about the movie?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, I really liked one of the scenes where they were fixing their bike together. It looked like a lot of work but also very satisfying when it was done.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: I can see why that would be appealing. Sounds like you're interested in hands-on activities and maybe even some problem-solving.

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: (laughs) Yeah, something like that.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That's interesting! Let's talk more about your hand and arm use. How have things been lately? Have you noticed any difficulty with everyday tasks or activities?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Actually, yes. I've been having some trouble opening jars, especially those with tight lids. My hands feel like they're not as strong as before the injury.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That makes sense. Can you tell me more about what happens when you try to open a jar? Do you experience any pain or discomfort?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: It's just really hard for me to get a grip on it, and my arm feels fatigued pretty quickly. Sometimes I have to use both hands or ask for help.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: I see. Have you noticed any issues with reaching or stretching your arms to grab things from high shelves or above your head?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: A bit. If I'm not careful, I can feel a strain in my shoulder and elbow when I try to reach up. It's not as bad if I just stretch forward, but it still feels like there's some tension there.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That makes sense given what you said about opening jars. Have you had to adapt any daily routines or activities because of these challenges?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, definitely. Folding laundry is a lot harder for me now, so I have to do smaller loads and take breaks more often.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: How do you feel about the progress you've made so far in terms of your hand and arm use?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Honestly, it's been frustrating at times. Some days my arms just don't want to cooperate, and I get really discouraged.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That's understandable. Do you have any support system or coping mechanisms that help on those hard days?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, my friends are great about reminding me of how far I've come and encouraging me to keep going. And my family has been super understanding, which helps a lot.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That sounds like a good support network. Have you found any activities or hobbies that you enjoy doing despite the challenges with your hands and arms?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Actually, yes. Drawing is something I still really love doing, even if it gets a bit more difficult for me now. It's nice to have that as an outlet.

patient_profile.disease: upper limb amputation with prosthetic rehabilitation

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Hi there! It's nice to meet you. How are you feeling today?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: I'm a bit anxious about our session, but otherwise okay, thanks.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Anxiety before a physical therapy session is completely normal. We'll work through your concerns together. Can you tell me a little about what brought you in today?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: To be honest, it's just been really frustrating trying to use my prosthetic arm for everyday tasks. It feels like I'm back where I started.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: I see. Using your prosthetic arm can be challenging at first, but we've made progress before. Let’s focus on what you're struggling with right now. Can you give me an example of something specific that's been giving you trouble?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: For instance, when I try to tie my shoelaces or even just turn a doorknob, it feels like the prosthetic is getting in the way.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That sounds really tough. Have you noticed any difficulties with other tasks that require coordinated actions of your arm and hand, like cutting food or using utensils?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Actually, yes. Cutting vegetables was okay before, but now even simple tasks feel more difficult because I'm worried about dropping things or losing control.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: It’s understandable to feel apprehensive about these challenges, especially with the added concern of controlling your prosthetic. Have you talked to anyone about how this is affecting you emotionally?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: My family and friends are supportive, but it's hard to explain what I'm feeling. Sometimes it feels like they don't really get it.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That can be tough. It sounds like you're not just dealing with the physical challenges of your prosthetic arm, but also emotional ones related to independence and control. Have you found any ways to cope with those feelings?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Just trying to stay positive and focus on small achievements. But it's hard when some days feel worse than others.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Absolutely. It’s a process, and we'll work through it together. Let’s set some achievable goals for our sessions going forward. What do you think would be a good starting point?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: I guess just getting more comfortable with my prosthetic arm in general, so daily tasks become easier.

patient_profile.disease: upper limb amputation with prosthetic rehabilitation

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Hi, welcome to our session today. How are you doing?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: I'm managing, thank you for asking. It's been a bit of an adjustment living without my arm, but I'm trying to stay positive.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That makes sense. It can be tough adjusting to changes in our bodies and lives. What have you found most challenging so far?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Honestly, it's the daily tasks that feel like a struggle. Simple things like tying my shoes or cooking meals are just harder now.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: I see. Can you tell me more about what specifically is difficult for you when doing these tasks? Is it pain, weakness, or something else?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: It's more like...I don't know how to explain it. My arm just doesn't feel as strong as it used to be, and that makes everything harder.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That must be frustrating. Can you give me an example of a time when this felt particularly difficult? Maybe something that happened recently?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yesterday, I was trying to make lunch for myself, but I struggled with opening the jar of sauce. My wrist just didn't want to budge.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: I can imagine. Did you feel like your arm was giving out on you, or were you able to push through and open it eventually?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: It took a while longer than usual, and by the time I finally managed to get the lid off, my hand felt really sore. So yeah, I'd say that's about right for where I'm at.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That makes sense. What about tasks like turning door handles or throwing objects? Are you able to do those with ease, or are there still some challenges?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Door handles are okay, but throwing is definitely harder now. If I try to throw something too hard, my elbow starts to feel a bit of pain.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That must make things tricky when trying to accomplish tasks that require both arms. Do you find yourself adapting in any way or relying on assistive tools?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, I've started using a special tool for opening jars and bottles now. It's been a big help, actually.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That sounds like it has really made things easier for you. How do you feel about the progress you've made so far? Is there anything that gives you hope or makes you feel more motivated?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Honestly, just getting through each day without too much struggle feels like a victory to me right now. And seeing how well I'm doing with tools and adaptations—like the jar opener—is really encouraging.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That's great to hear! It sounds like you're finding ways to cope and adapt that are working for you. Do you have any friends or family members who help support you through this time?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, my wife has been a huge help. She's always there with encouragement and a listening ear when I need it.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That must be really valuable to have her support. Are there any other things that might help you stay motivated or feel more positive about your situation?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Actually, just focusing on the small wins each day seems to keep me going. And like I said, having my wife's support is a big part of that.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That makes sense. Well, it was great talking with you today and hearing about how you're adapting to these challenges. Remember, we can work together to find even more ways to make things easier for you.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Hi, welcome to our clinic. How are you doing today?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: I'm doing well, thanks for asking. A bit nervous about this appointment, but I guess it's better than not coming.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That makes sense. We're here to help you with any concerns or issues you might have. Can you tell me a bit about what brings you in today?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, my upper limb spasticity has been pretty consistent for years now. But lately, I've noticed it's getting worse when I'm trying to manipulate things like utensils or even simple tasks at home.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Can you give me an example of what happens when you try to use a fork?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Well, it's hard to describe. But basically, my hand wants to grip too tightly and my fingers get all cramped up. I end up dropping the fork or using both hands instead of one.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: And how about with bottles or cans? Do you have trouble opening them?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah. It takes me a lot longer than anyone else. My wrist gets tired easily, so it's hard to twist open even something light like a water bottle.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: I see. Have you found any strategies that help make these tasks easier for you?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Not really. Sometimes I just have to take my time and be more patient with myself. But it can get frustrating when I'm trying to cook or clean up after meals.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That makes sense. How about using tools like adaptive utensils or specialized grips? Have you looked into those at all?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Actually, a friend recommended some silicone grip helpers for my hands, but I haven't tried them yet.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: It sounds like managing these tasks can be really challenging. How do you feel about your progress so far?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Honestly, it's hard to stay positive when everything feels like a struggle. But I guess that's why I'm here, right? To get some help and figure out what works best for me.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That's a great attitude! It takes a lot of courage to face these challenges head-on. What do you think might be the biggest change you'd like to see in your daily life if we could work together on this issue?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Well, I guess just being able to do everyday tasks without feeling so overwhelmed would be amazing. And maybe having more confidence in my abilities too.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Hi, how are you doing today?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: I'm a bit nervous about our session today. It's been three months since my stroke, and I still struggle with basic tasks.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That takes courage to admit. Can you tell me more about what's been challenging for you lately?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Simple things like cooking dinner or even opening jars have become so much harder. My hand just doesn't cooperate sometimes.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Let's focus on the ICF category of D445, which is performing coordinated actions required for moving objects or manipulating them by using hands and arms. Can you give me an example of something specific you've been struggling with?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Like I said, opening jars or even turning door handles becomes a struggle. It feels like my wrist doesn't have enough strength to do these everyday tasks.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That sounds frustrating. Have you noticed any difference in your ability to grip objects or perform fine motor movements?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, gripping things like pens is okay, but anything heavier than that is hard for me. And even simple actions like buttoning my shirt take a lot of effort now.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: I see. How about when you're doing tasks that require twisting your arm, such as pouring liquids or reaching into high cabinets?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Those are actually some of the toughest things for me right now. It feels like my elbow gets in the way and makes it hard to reach far or twist without straining.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That's really insightful. Have you found any strategies that help you cope with these challenges, especially when they make you feel frustrated?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Well, I try not to push myself too hard and take more breaks than before. And sometimes, if I'm feeling overwhelmed, I just ask for help from family members or friends. It's hard to admit it, but it really helps me conserve energy for the things that are truly important to me.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: How do you feel about your progress so far?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Honestly, it feels like I'm taking steps back sometimes. Simple tasks take longer than they should, and I worry that my arm is just not strong enough for the things I need to do.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That must be really tough on your confidence. Have you talked to anyone about these feelings?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, my family doctor said it's common to experience setbacks after a stroke, but he also emphasized the importance of taking care of myself and being patient. It helps a bit.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Being patient is hard, especially when you see others doing things with ease that are still challenging for you. Do you feel like there are any daily activities or tasks that you've had to adapt in order to manage your condition?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, definitely. I have to take more breaks while cooking and ask my partner to help with some chores around the house. It's hard not being independent in those ways, but it feels better than risking injury by pushing myself too much.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That makes sense. What do you think is the biggest challenge for you right now? Is it the physical limitations or something else entirely?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: I'd say it's a mix of both. The physical stuff is hard to deal with, but also seeing others doing things that seem so easy and feeling like I'm missing out on some normal life experiences is tough too.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Can you tell me more about what happens when you're trying to perform tasks related to D445 and it becomes challenging?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Like turning door handles or opening jars, my wrist feels really weak. It's hard for me to generate enough force without straining or using too much effort. Sometimes I get frustrated because it feels like my arm just isn't strong enough yet.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That makes sense. Have you noticed any patterns or times of day when your strength seems to be better?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, mornings are usually a bit easier for me. After some warm-up exercises and getting moving, I feel like I can handle more tasks without as much strain. But by the afternoon, it starts to wear off, and my arm feels tired again.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That's really interesting. Does that impact your daily routine or planning in any way? For example, do you try to schedule harder tasks for morning when your strength is better?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, I definitely plan around it now. Mornings are when I focus on the most challenging tasks, like grocery shopping or heavy household chores. Afternoons are usually reserved for lighter stuff that doesn't require as much physical effort.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Can you describe a particularly challenging situation where your arm strength was needed but wasn't quite up to par?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: One time I tried to lift my niece, who's about two years old, out of her crib. My arms were tired from doing laundry earlier, and even though I knew it wouldn't be easy, I thought I could manage. But when I lifted her up, my arm just gave way under the weight, and she fell back into the crib. It was really scary for me to see that happen, especially since she's still little and can get hurt easily.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That must have been very concerning for you. How did you feel about your body's limitations in that moment? Did it make you question your own strength or abilities?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, I definitely felt frustrated with myself. It made me realize just how far my arm is still from being as strong as it was before the stroke. It's hard to accept that some things take longer than others and that sometimes you just have to admit when you need help.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: How do you feel about your overall progress so far?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Honestly, it feels like I'm taking two steps forward and one step back most of the time. Some days are better than others, but it's hard not to compare myself to where I was before my stroke.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That comparison can be really tough, especially when you see how far you've come in some areas and still struggle with others. Have you found any strategies or ways to cope with those feelings of frustration?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, one thing that helps is focusing on the small victories, like managing a full day without needing a nap or being able to do more household chores than I could before. It's not perfect, but it feels like progress, and that keeps me motivated.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Hi there, it's great to meet you. How are you doing today?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: I'm okay, just a bit fatigued after a long morning of medication and physical therapy.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Sorry to hear that. Fatigue can be challenging. What's been on your mind lately? Is anything specific bothering you about your condition or daily life?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Honestly, it's my hand function that's been the biggest concern. I just feel like I'm not as steady as I used to be, and simple tasks are becoming really frustrating.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That makes sense. Hand and arm use can be affected by multiple sclerosis. Can you tell me more about what you're experiencing? What kind of tasks have been giving you trouble?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Well, even something like pouring a glass of water feels like a struggle. My hand just doesn't seem to want to do what I'm telling it to do. And opening jars is basically impossible without help now.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That must be really frustrating for you. Can you think of any specific situations where your hand function affects your daily life? For instance, cooking or personal hygiene?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, cooking's been a challenge lately. I used to love trying new recipes, but now it feels like I'm just going through the motions because I have to. And getting dressed in the morning is a bit of an ordeal because I need help tying my shoes and buttoning up shirts.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That’s really hard. Have you noticed any patterns or triggers that might make these symptoms worse? For example, do they seem to be better after rest or exacerbated by stress?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Actually, yes. If I'm under a lot of stress, it feels like my coordination and strength just drop even further. And if I overexert myself physically, the next day is always worse for my hand function.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That makes sense. It sounds like you're trying to manage not just your physical symptoms but also your mental well-being. How do these challenges make you feel?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Frustrated and a bit anxious, to be honest. I feel like I'm losing control over simple things that used to come easily to me. And it's hard not to worry about what the future holds for my condition.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That's completely understandable. It takes courage to acknowledge these feelings. Have you talked to anyone about how you're feeling? Family, friends, a therapist perhaps?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, I talk to my wife about it sometimes. She’s very supportive, but it's hard for her to understand what it's like living with this condition day in and day out. And sometimes I feel guilty for being a burden on her.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That guilt is a heavy load to carry. It might be helpful to explore ways to communicate your needs more clearly or find other sources of emotional support, like a support group or online forums. What do you think about trying some new coping strategies?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: I suppose it couldn't hurt to try something new. I've been so focused on managing my symptoms that I haven’t really thought much about how I feel emotionally.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Hi, how are you doing today? It’s nice to meet you. Can I get your name and age for my records?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: My name is Sarah, and I’m 43 years old.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Nice to meet you too, Sarah! How have you been lately? Any changes in your daily life or mood that we should know about?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Honestly, I’ve been feeling a bit frustrated. Simple tasks are taking longer than they used to, and it’s hard for me to keep up with my friends.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That can be really tough. It sounds like there might be some challenges related to using your hands and arms. Can you tell me more about what you mean by that?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah... I guess so. Like yesterday, I was trying to put groceries away in the kitchen, but I struggled to lift a heavy bag onto the counter. And then, when I tried to open the jar of pasta sauce, my hand got really cramped.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That must have been really frustrating. Let’s explore this further. What do you think is making it harder for you to perform these tasks? Is it just your physical strength or something else as well?

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: So, when you say you struggled to lift the bag, was there any pain involved? Or was it more about not being able to generate enough force?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: It’s a mix of both. Sometimes my arms feel really weak and I worry that if I try too hard, I might strain something. But other times, like yesterday with the jar, my hand just gets really tight and I can’t open it no matter how hard I try.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That makes sense. Have you ever noticed any difficulty with twisting your wrists or turning doorknobs? For example, if someone asks you to turn a key in a lock or grasp something with both hands?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah... doorknobs are fine for me most of the time, but opening jars is still really hard. And if I need to twist my arm to reach something high up, like in a cabinet, it feels a bit uncomfortable.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Okay, got it. How about carrying things, like bags or boxes? Do you find yourself using any strategies or aids to help with this?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Actually, yes! I use a cart sometimes when shopping so that I can carry more items without straining my arms. And at home, I try to keep things organized and within reach.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That’s really smart thinking! Are there daily activities you’ve had to adapt or take slower because of these challenges?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah... laundry is one example. Folding clothes takes longer now that I have to use both hands. And cooking can be harder too – sometimes my arms get tired from stirring or lifting heavy pots.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: How do you feel about the progress you’ve made so far? Is there anything in particular that’s giving you hope or motivation?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Honestly, it’s been tough to see myself struggle with things I used to take for granted. But at the same time, I’m proud of how hard I’ve been trying and adapting my daily life accordingly.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That takes a lot of courage! Have you found any strategies or support systems that help you cope on harder days?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah... talking to friends and family about what I’m going through really helps. And focusing on small wins, like managing the laundry or playing with my cat, reminds me that I am getting stronger.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That’s a great approach! It sounds like your loved ones are very supportive – do you find yourself leaning on them more often now?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yes... they’ve been amazing through all this. They remind me of how far I’ve come and encourage me to keep pushing forward.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Well, it was wonderful speaking with you today, Sarah. Remember that we’ll work together to find ways to make your daily life easier and more manageable.

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Thank you, doctor. Just talking about this has already made me feel a bit better.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Hello, welcome to our clinic. How are you feeling today?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: I'm a bit apprehensive about coming here, but I guess it's been long enough since my last appointment. My arms have been hurting more lately.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Sorry to hear that. Can you tell me a little bit about what's been going on with your arms? What kind of activities are giving you trouble?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Well, everything is hard when it comes to using my hands and arms. Even simple tasks like cooking or dressing take me longer than they used to.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: I see. And how would you rate the difficulty level of these tasks? On a scale from 1 to 10, with 1 being no trouble at all and 10 being extremely difficult?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: It's more like an 8 for me right now. Some days are better than others, but overall, my arms just feel so weak.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Okay, let's explore some of these tasks in more detail. When you're cooking, do you find that your hands and arms get tired quickly?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, especially when I'm chopping vegetables or stirring pots. My wrist and elbow start to ache after a while.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That makes sense. How about when you're turning door handles or opening jars? Do you have trouble with those tasks too?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Actually, it's more like... my hands don't always want to cooperate. Sometimes they feel stiff, and I struggle to get the handle turned. It's frustrating.

dialogue.speaker: doctor

dialogue.content: Sorry to hear that. Can you tell me more about what's been going on with your arm? What do you mean by "stiff"?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: I have cerebral palsy, and my muscles get all spastic sometimes. When it happens, it feels like my arm is stuck or locked up. It's really hard to move around then.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: I see. That sounds challenging. Have you noticed any specific situations or activities that trigger this stiffness?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah... things like turning doorknobs or opening jars are super hard when my muscles are being spastic. And it feels like my arm gets even weaker after those tasks.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Got it. How would you describe the impact of these challenges on your daily life? Do you have to adapt your activities in any way?

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Can you give me an example of a time when this stiffness really affected something important for you?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Okay... last week, I needed to carry groceries from the car into my apartment. My arm was being really spastic that day, and it took me like 10 minutes to just open the door and grab one bag. It's usually not that hard.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That sounds frustrating. Did you have any trouble reaching or lifting anything else during those groceries?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah... I had to take a break halfway through because my arm was getting so tired. I ended up dropping some stuff, which was a mess.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: I can imagine how upsetting that must be. Have you found ways to manage this stiffness at all? Do you have any strategies or tools that help?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Well... I've been trying to do more exercises and stretches to loosen my muscles. It's not always easy, but it seems like it helps a bit. And sometimes taking breaks really helps too.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That makes sense. What about reaching into high spaces or overhead—do you ever struggle with those activities?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Oh yeah... that's super hard when I'm feeling spastic. I have to be really careful not to strain my arm, which is hard because I need to get stuff down from the top shelves sometimes.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Got it. How about carrying or lifting heavier objects—do you feel like your arm gets in the way of doing those tasks?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah... definitely. It's like my arm just gives up after a while and won't lift anything heavy.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: How do these challenges make you feel most often? Do they cause more frustration or anxiety for you?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Honestly, it's usually a mix of both. Sometimes I get really frustrated because I know my arm could be stronger if I didn't have cerebral palsy. And other times, especially on harder days, I just feel anxious about not being able to do things like everyone else seems to.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That makes sense. Do you find any ways to cope with those feelings? Any people or activities that help you stay positive?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah... my friends and family are really supportive. They remind me of all the things I can still do, even if it's harder sometimes. And playing with Timo is always a mood booster for me.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Hi there, thank you for coming in today. How are you feeling?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: I'm a bit anxious about my arm, to be honest. It's been giving me trouble since the injury.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: I can imagine that would be concerning. Let's talk about what's been going on with your arm. Can you tell me more about it?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Well, I was lifting something at home and suddenly felt this sharp pain in my shoulder. Ever since then, moving my arm has just felt...different. It hurts when I try to lift things or even just move it around normally.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That sounds very uncomfortable. Have you noticed any difficulty with specific movements? For example, reaching up high or turning door handles?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, everything is harder now. Even simple tasks take longer because my arm feels so weak. And when I do try to lift things, the pain shoots through my shoulder and down into my arm. It's like a constant ache.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That must be really frustrating for you. Have you been able to continue with your daily activities without too much trouble?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: No, not really. Lifting groceries is almost impossible now. And even simple things like pouring water from the kettle or opening jars are hard because I have to strain my arm so much. It's just exhausting.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That sounds very challenging. How does this impact your daily life emotionally? Do you feel anxious or frustrated about these limitations?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: All of the above! Sometimes it feels like I'm losing control over even the smallest things, and that's scary for me. But my husband is really supportive, so he helps me find ways to adapt and make do with what I can manage.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That’s great to hear about your support system. And what about coping strategies? Do you have any activities or practices that help you feel better when these challenges arise?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Well, like I said, my husband is a big help. But also, just taking it one step at a time and focusing on the things I can do rather than getting too caught up in what I can’t do seems to help. And, of course, there's Timo—he’s always happy to see me, no matter how I'm feeling!

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: (laughs) That sounds wonderful. It was great talking with you today about your arm and daily life. Is there anything else you'd like to talk about or any questions you have?

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Hi, it's nice to meet you. How are you doing today?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: I'm a bit tired, but that's normal for me. I've been trying to get some rest when I can.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That makes sense. It takes a lot of energy to deal with cerebral palsy and upper limb spasticity. What brings you in here today?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: My doctor referred me because my condition has been getting worse. The spasticity is affecting my daily activities more than ever before.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: I see. Can you tell me a bit about what's been happening at home? How are your hands and arms doing?

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Specifically, how do you find yourself performing with tasks that require hand and arm use, like turning door handles or throwing objects?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: It's really hard for me. Simple things take a lot of effort and planning because I have to anticipate which muscles will get in the way.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That must be frustrating. Can you give me an example of something that was manageable last week but is now challenging due to your spasticity?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yes, just opening jars or bottles. If I don't have a special opener, it's almost impossible for me because my arm gets stuck in the way.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That sounds like a significant challenge. Are there any particular times of day when you feel more or less affected by this spasticity?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Morning is usually the worst. After waking up and not moving much at night, my muscles are really tight and stiff. It takes me a while to get going.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: And what about activities that require reaching overhead or extending your arms out for a long period of time? Do you find that this causes any particular discomfort or limitation?

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: How do these challenges affect you emotionally? Do you feel frustrated, anxious, or defeated at times?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Honestly, it's hard not to. It feels like I'm losing my independence piece by piece. Simple tasks become big hurdles. Sometimes I get really down about it.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That's understandable. Have you talked with anyone about how you're feeling? Do you have any support or strategies that help you cope?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: My family is supportive, and they try to understand what I'm going through. But sometimes just talking about it helps me feel like I'm not alone in this fight. And I've been trying to focus on small victories each day, no matter how small. It keeps me moving forward.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** Good morning, how are you doing today? I'm glad we could meet this morning.

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** Hi. Yeah, I'm okay. My day's been a bit rough so far, but we'll see how it goes.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** Sorry to hear that. Would you like to tell me a little about what's on your mind right now?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** Well... just feeling really stuck with some things at home. Like, simple stuff – opening jars, carrying groceries, even doing my hair... it feels like such an effort all the time.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** That sounds really frustrating. Let's talk more about those specific tasks that are giving you trouble. When you're trying to open a jar, for example, what do you find yourself struggling with?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** It's just getting leverage on the lid. Sometimes I'll use one hand and then have to switch to the other because it feels too heavy or hard to grip. And even when I get it open, my arm gets tired easily.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** Okay. So it seems like your upper limb spasticity is affecting not only the strength in your arms but also your ability to perform fine motor tasks and use your hands effectively. Are there any particular situations where you feel this more or less?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** Yeah... mornings are usually worse, I think because my muscles are stiffer. But it's always hard when I need to do something with both hands, like carrying groceries up the stairs.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** That makes sense. And have you noticed anything else that might be affecting how you're able to use your arms and hands in these situations?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** Yeah... my shoulder sometimes feels really tight or sore if I'm doing too much lifting or reaching overhead.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** Okay, got it. How about emotions? When you're struggling with these kinds of tasks, how do you feel? Frustrated, anxious...

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** Definitely frustrated. And a bit sad because I know what my life was like before... when I could just pick up my grandkids from school without getting tired.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** It sounds like there's a lot of emotional weight to this for you. Do you have any support system or things that help you cope on harder days?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** Yeah, my family's really understanding and helpful. And just taking it one step at a time – breaking down bigger tasks into smaller ones, taking breaks when I need them...

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** That's great advice. It sounds like you're already doing some of the things that we can work on together to make progress.

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** Yeah... I guess so. Thanks for listening and understanding what I'm going through.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** Hi, thank you for coming in today. How are you feeling about your upper limbs lately?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** Honestly, it's been a bit frustrating. Simple things like dressing and cooking take longer than they used to.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** I can imagine. Can you tell me more about what's specifically challenging? Is it the strength, flexibility, or coordination of your arms?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** It's a bit of everything, but if I had to choose...I think it's the hand and arm use, especially with fine motor tasks. Opening jars, turning doorknobs, those kinds of things.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** Got it. So, let's dive into some specific examples. How about opening packages or bags? Do you find that takes a lot of effort?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** Yes, definitely. If the bag is too heavy or has zippers, I struggle to open it without straining my wrist and elbow.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** Okay, that makes sense. And what about pouring liquids from a container, like water or juice?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** That's still hard for me. My hand tends to shake when I'm holding the jug or bottle, so I have to be very careful not to spill anything.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** It sounds like you're being quite cautious. Have there been any situations where you've felt anxious or frustrated due to these challenges?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** Absolutely. Sometimes I get upset because I feel like my limitations are getting worse. Simple things that used to be easy now take so much more time and effort, which makes me worry about losing independence.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** That must be really tough for you. Have you talked to anyone about how you're feeling? Do you have any emotional support or strategies to cope with these challenges?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** I've been talking to my family a bit more, but it's hard to explain what I'm going through. They don't fully understand why some tasks are just so much harder for me now.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** That can be really isolating. Are there any things that you enjoy or find motivating when faced with these challenges?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** Actually, yes. Spending time in nature helps me a lot. Walking my dog and playing fetch is something I look forward to every day. It reminds me that even though some tasks are hard, life is still enjoyable.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** That's wonderful! Nature can be very therapeutic. Finally, what do you hope to achieve or see improve with your upper limb function in the coming months?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** I'd love to regain more independence, especially with daily activities like cooking and cleaning. If I could get back to doing those things without straining my arms so much, that would make a huge difference for me.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** That sounds like a great goal. We'll work together to see what progress we can make towards achieving that. Thank you for sharing your story with me today!

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Hello, thank you for coming in today. I'm glad we could schedule this appointment to discuss your hand and arm use. How are you feeling overall?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Hi, I'm doing alright, considering everything. My MS has been a bit of a challenge lately, but I try to stay positive.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That's great to hear! It takes a lot of strength to manage your condition. Can you tell me a little about what brings you here today? What are some specific difficulties you've been experiencing with your hands and arms?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Well, it seems like my coordination has gotten a bit worse lately. Simple tasks like cooking or even just turning door handles have become more difficult. It's frustrating, especially since I used to be able to do these things easily.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That does sound frustrating. Can you give me some examples of specific situations where you've noticed this difficulty? For instance, are there any particular activities that you find harder now than they used to be?

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Okay, so it sounds like everyday tasks have become a bit more challenging for you. How about reaching or extending your arm—does that feel different too?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, definitely. When I try to reach up high, my elbow feels like it's going to strain, and sometimes my hand feels numb. It's hard to explain exactly what happens.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That makes sense. So it's not just about the strength of your arm but also the sensation you get from your nerves. Have you noticed any changes in how things feel when you're carrying objects or doing tasks that require both arms?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Actually, yes. When I carry groceries or something like that, my arms start to ache after a while. It's not just the weight of the items but also the way they feel in my hands and wrists.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That must be quite uncomfortable. Have you tried using any adaptive devices or tools to make these tasks easier? For example, do you use ergonomic handles on your walking aids or assistive grips for carrying things?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: I have looked into a few of those options, but it's hard to find something that really works well with my condition. Sometimes the solutions end up being more cumbersome than they're worth.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That's understandable. We can definitely explore some options together. How about turning door handles or operating faucets—have you found ways to make these tasks easier?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: It's been a challenge, but I've started using my feet to push open doors and use a faucet with a long handle that's easier to turn.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: How do you feel about the progress we're making today? Do you have any concerns or worries about your hand and arm function?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Honestly, it's been helpful to talk through these challenges with someone who understands. I just wish I could find more solutions that work for me. It feels like a lot of things are designed for people without disabilities.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That makes sense. You're not alone in feeling frustrated by the lack of accessibility and accommodations. Have you talked to anyone else about this or sought out any support groups?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Actually, I've been trying to connect with some online communities and forums for people with MS. It's nice to know I'm not the only one facing these issues.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Hi, Sarah. Welcome to our therapy session today. How are you feeling?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: I'm feeling a bit anxious about my hands lately. It's been a few days since the last flare-up, but I've noticed some stiffness in my fingers and wrists.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Sorry to hear that. Staying on top of your rheumatoid arthritis can be challenging. Have you had any changes in your routine or environment recently?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Actually, I just started taking up painting as a hobby. It's something I've always wanted to try, but I'm not sure if my hands will cooperate.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That sounds like a fun way to express yourself creatively! I'd love to hear more about how you're finding it with your hands.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: So, can you tell me more about what's happening with your hand functions? Are there any specific tasks or movements that are becoming harder for you?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Well, gripping and twisting objects is still a struggle. I had trouble opening my water bottle this morning. It's not as painful as it used to be, but it feels like my hands are just not working together properly.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Have you noticed any changes in your range of motion or flexibility since the flare-up?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, definitely. My fingers feel a bit stiff when I try to bend them backward or forward. It's not as flexible as before, and sometimes it feels like my hands are locking up on me.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Okay, that makes sense. And how about fine motor tasks like writing, buttoning shirts, or tying shoelaces? Are those becoming more difficult for you?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Writing is still okay, but buttoning is getting trickier. I have to use a lot of force and sometimes struggle with the buttons feeling stuck in place.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Got it. And what about everyday activities like cooking, cleaning, or personal hygiene? Have you had to adapt your routine at all?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, definitely. Lifting heavy objects is out of the question for now, so I've been trying to use assistive devices more often.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: How do you feel about the progress you've made so far with your hand functions?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Honestly, it's a bit frustrating that my hands are still struggling. But at the same time, I'm proud of myself for pushing through the pain and trying new things like painting. It feels good to have some creative outlet, even if it's just a small part of my life right now.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That makes sense. Have you talked to anyone about how you're feeling, or do you feel like you're managing these emotions on your own?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: I've been trying to talk to friends and family more often. It helps to have someone listen and remind me that I'm not alone in this. Sometimes just having a listening ear makes all the difference.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That's great advice. And it sounds like you're finding ways to stay positive despite the challenges your RA is presenting. Is there anything you'd like to work on or focus on during our therapy sessions moving forward?

dialogue.content: ** That's a fair assessment. And finally, how do these challenges make you feel? Do they affect your mood or overall outlook on life?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** Definitely. It's hard not to get frustrated when things are tough like this. But I'm trying to stay positive and focus on small victories. Like today, for instance! We're making progress, even if it feels slow sometimes.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** That's exactly the right attitude to have. And don't forget that you've got a great support system here at the clinic – we'll be with you every step of the way as you work through these challenges.

patient_profile.disease: upper limb amputation with prosthetic rehabilitation

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Hi, it's nice to see you again. How are you feeling today?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: I'm doing alright, considering everything. It's just been a few weeks since the surgery, so my arm still feels quite sore.

dialogue.content: That makes sense. Physical therapy can be tough, especially right after an injury like this. What have you been up to lately? Anything that's been bringing you some joy or keeping your mind off things?

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That sounds wonderful! Family can be such a great source of comfort and strength during tough times. What do you think has been the biggest challenge so far in terms of adapting to life with your new prosthetic?

dialogue.speaker: patient

dialogue.content: Okay, got it. And what about when you're reaching or stretching your arm out? Do you feel any discomfort or pain in your shoulder or elbow area?

dialogue.content: Okay, we can work on some exercises to help strengthen that area and improve your range of motion. How about when you're carrying things like groceries or bags? Do you feel like you have enough control over the items in your hand, or do you worry about dropping them?

dialogue.speaker: patient

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That makes sense. It can be really frustrating when we feel like our bodies aren't cooperating with us the way they used to. How do you think this experience has affected your overall outlook or mood?

dialogue.content: Honestly, it's been tough at times. There are days when I feel pretty down and discouraged about my progress. But my family and friends have been really supportive, and that helps a lot.

dialogue.content: That's great to hear! It's wonderful that you have such a strong support system behind you. Have you found any specific coping mechanisms or strategies that help you deal with the emotional ups and downs of this process?

dialogue.content: Yeah, I've started keeping a journal to track my progress and reflect on how far I've come. It helps me see things from a different perspective and remember all the small victories along the way.

dialogue.content: ** Hi, how are you doing today? It's nice to see you again.

dialogue.content: ** That's good. Now, I wanted to talk to you more specifically about using your hands and arms. You've mentioned some difficulties in the past, especially when it comes to activities like cooking or grooming. Can you tell me more about what you're experiencing?

dialogue.content: ** Well... Cooking is still a bit of a challenge for me. Sometimes my fingers just don't want to grip the utensils properly, and I end up dropping them.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** I see. And how about opening jars or bottles? Is that something you've had trouble with lately?
