dialogue.content: That must make you feel very frustrated and dependent on others. Can you think of any specific situations where your hand and arm function is really limited? For example, how about when you're trying to take a shower or bathe?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, showers are a nightmare for me now. I have to use these special grips on the handles because my hands just can't hold onto anything else. And even then, it's not like I can stand under the water for long without needing help to get out of the way of the spray. It feels so embarrassing and weak.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That sounds incredibly difficult. Have you noticed any difference in your ability to grip or manipulate objects at all? For instance, are there things that were easier for you before that now feel really hard?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, everything's harder. Even holding a cup of coffee is a challenge because the weight and the shape just don't feel right in my hands anymore. And trying to button up my shirt or tie my shoelaces... Forget about it. Those are done by others now too.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: How do you find your endurance with these tasks? Do you have to take breaks often, or is there a point where you just can't keep going?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: I do take a lot of breaks, and sometimes even then, my body feels so exhausted afterwards that I need some time to recover before trying again. It's hard to explain, but it's like my arms are just giving up on me.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That must be incredibly discouraging for you. How do these challenges make you feel about yourself?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Honestly, it makes me feel pretty hopeless at times. I've always been independent and strong, so to not be able to take care of myself anymore is hard to accept. But when I see others doing the same things without issue, it just makes me feel like there's something wrong with me. Like I'm broken somehow.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That's understandable. Have you talked to anyone about how you're feeling? Do you have any support or people who understand what you're going through?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, my family has been really supportive and understanding. They know that it's not just the physical limitations but also the emotional toll of all this. So they try their best to be patient with me and help in whatever way they can.

patient_profile.disease: upper limb amputation with prosthetic rehabilitation

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Hi there, how are you feeling today?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: I'm a bit frustrated, to be honest. It's been two months since the accident, and some things just aren't getting easier yet.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: I can imagine. That must be really tough. What was it like when you first woke up after your surgery?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Scary. The pain was overwhelming, and not being able to use my arm or hand at all made me feel so helpless.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: It sounds like a very difficult time. Have things been improving gradually since then, or is there something specific that's causing you frustration now?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: It feels like some days are better than others, but I still struggle with just about everything. Opening jars, even simple things like turning door handles... it all feels so hard.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Can you tell me more about what specifically is challenging for you in these situations? Is it the strength required or something else entirely?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: It's definitely the coordination and fine motor skills that are tough. For example, trying to turn a door handle without twisting my wrist just doesn't work well yet. And reaching high shelves? Forget about it. I have to rely on others for even basic tasks now.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That must be very frustrating. Are there certain times of the day or situations where your arm feels more tired than usual, making these activities even harder?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, mornings are usually the worst. After a night's sleep, my arm just feels heavy and stiff. And on bad days, even simple tasks like brushing my teeth can be difficult.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: I see. It sounds like there might be some fatigue at play here as well. Are you finding it more challenging to perform these tasks in different settings or environments? For instance, how about when you're out and about versus at home?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Out is definitely harder. Trying to navigate public spaces with my prosthetic can be really overwhelming. People stare a lot, which just adds to the stress.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That must be very challenging to deal with both physically and emotionally. How do you feel about these challenges overall?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Honestly? It's hard not to get frustrated sometimes. But I'm trying really hard not to let it consume me. I keep reminding myself that I've come so far already, even if it doesn't feel like it some days.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That's a great attitude to have! Do you find anything particularly supportive or helpful in navigating these challenges?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, my family and close friends are amazing. They're always there for me, no matter what. And I've started seeing a counselor as well, which has been super helpful in just talking through all the emotions that come with this experience.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Hi, it's great to see you today. How are you feeling?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: I'm doing well, thanks for asking. It's nice to be here.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That's wonderful! What have you been up to lately that brings you joy?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Actually, I started painting again last week and found it really relaxing.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Oh, how lovely! Painting is such a great way to express yourself creatively. Do you find it helps with your hand movements or arm control in any way?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Hmm, not directly, but I do get to exercise my hand more when holding the brushes.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That's an interesting connection! How about when you're doing everyday tasks like cooking or cleaning? Are there things that are still a bit challenging for you?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, lifting heavy pots and pans is still tricky. I have to use both arms together or else my shoulder gets sore.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: I see. Have you noticed any improvement in your ability to carry groceries or bags over time?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, it's gotten easier. But I still get tired if I'm carrying too much at once.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Okay, that makes sense. What about when you're using tools like scissors or clippers? Do you have trouble with those?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Actually, no! Those are some of the easiest things for me to do now. It's a good feeling to be able to use them confidently.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That must give you a sense of accomplishment. How does it make you feel when you're able to do tasks that were harder before?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Honestly, it feels amazing! I get this surge of confidence and motivation to keep pushing myself.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That's wonderful! Do you ever worry about losing progress or slipping back into old patterns?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, definitely. But my family and friends are really supportive, and they remind me how far I've come.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That's great to hear. It sounds like you have a strong support system in place.

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, it makes all the difference.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Hi, Mr. Thompson. Thank you for coming in today. How are you feeling about your arm and hand function lately?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Honestly, I've been having a tough time with the physical therapy exercises. My arm gets so tired.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: I can imagine that would be frustrating. Can you tell me more about what's specifically challenging for you? Is it just the pain or also the ability to perform daily tasks?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: It's mostly the pain and stiffness in my shoulder. Simple things like getting dressed or cooking are hard because I have to move my arm in ways that hurt.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: I see. Those activities can be really basic but require a lot of effort when you're not feeling well. Can you think of any specific situations where your hand or arm use is severely impacted?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Well, I struggle with opening jars or using heavy objects like pots and pans without assistance.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That must be really difficult. Have you noticed any patterns to when these difficulties are worse? For example, do they change throughout the day or in different positions?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, my arm feels worst in the morning after a night's rest. As I move around and warm up, it gets slightly better.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Okay, that makes sense. Can you walk me through some of those daily tasks I mentioned earlier? How do you typically manage opening jars or using pots and pans?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: For jars, I usually use my teeth to open them because my hand can't grip the lid tightly enough. With pots and pans, my partner has to help lift them onto the stovetop.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That sounds like a lot of adaptation is happening in your daily routine. How about reaching or extending your arm? Do you have any trouble with that?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yes, definitely. Even simple actions like brushing my teeth or washing my face can be painful if I stretch too far.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That must make you feel really limited in what you can do on your own. How does it affect you emotionally?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Honestly, it's hard not to feel frustrated or anxious about my progress sometimes. But I try to focus on the small steps forward and remind myself that this is a process.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That's very mature of you, considering everything. Have you talked to anyone close to you about how you're feeling? Do they offer any support?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, my partner and family are really understanding. They help me when I need it and encourage me to keep pushing forward.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That's great that you have their support. Before we wrap up today, is there anything on your mind or anything else you'd like to share about how this experience has been for you?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Just that I'm hoping it won't be too long before I can do more things without assistance.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Hi there, thank you for coming in today. How's your day been so far?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: It's been okay. Just getting through the morning routine was tough. I had some trouble brushing my teeth and washing my face. My arm just feels so stiff.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Sorry to hear that. That can be really frustrating. Can you tell me more about what happens when you try to brush your teeth?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Well, I have to use both hands because the one with cerebral palsy isn't very strong or coordinated. But even then, it's hard to get the toothbrush to move in small circles. It feels like my arm is just flopping around. And when I try to wash my face, the water just keeps splashing everywhere because I can't hold the cup steady.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That must be really challenging for you. How about doing things like opening jars or twisting bottle caps?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Honestly, no. Those are the kinds of tasks that make me feel most trapped and helpless. If someone else isn't around to help, I just can't do it on my own. Even simple things like turning door handles get tricky for me.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Can you describe what happens when you try to turn a door handle? Is there any pain or discomfort involved?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: It's not so much the physical act of turning the handle that hurts, but more like...I don't know how else to put it—my arm just feels like it's going to give out on me. Like it's stuck in one position and can't move at all.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That makes sense. How about reaching for things above you or off to the side? Do you find yourself leaning or bending in ways that might be hard on your back?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, definitely. I try to avoid reaching too high because it puts pressure on my lower back. But sometimes I just need something from a shelf, and I have to do it anyway. It's like...my body is betraying me.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That must be really tough for you to deal with. How do you feel about needing help with these kinds of tasks?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Honestly, it feels like a huge loss of independence. Like I'm not capable anymore. And sometimes it makes me angry, too. Why can't my body just work the way everyone else's does?

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That's understandable. Have you found any ways to cope or manage these feelings when they come up?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Well, I've been trying to focus on what I can do instead of getting bogged down by what I can't do. And sometimes it helps to remind myself that this is just part of who I am. But other times...it's hard not to feel like giving up.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Hi, how are you doing today?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: I'm a bit anxious. My hands have been hurting lately, and it's affecting my daily activities.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: I can imagine that would be frustrating. Can you tell me more about what's been going on with your hands?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: It started with just stiffness in the mornings, but over time it's gotten worse. Now even simple tasks like cooking or typing feel challenging.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Have you noticed any swelling or redness in your wrists or fingers?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: No, not really. But my hands do feel stiff and heavy, especially if I try to lift anything heavy.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That sounds a bit debilitating. Can you tell me more about the specific tasks that are giving you trouble?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Anything that involves gripping or twisting, like opening jars or turning door handles. It's hard for me to get a good grip on things.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: And what about carrying groceries or bags? Do you have any difficulty with those tasks?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, definitely. If I carry too much, my hands start to feel really tired and sore. Sometimes I drop things because they're too heavy for me.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That must be scary and frustrating. Have you found any ways to adapt or work around these challenges?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Well, I try to use assistive devices like jar openers or reachers when I need to. And I've started lifting lighter weights at the gym to see if that can help strengthen my hands.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Those are great strategies. How about reaching for things overhead or stretching your arms out to grab something? Do you have any difficulty with those tasks?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, it's hard for me to reach up high without feeling like I'm going to drop whatever I'm holding.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: It sounds like these challenges are not only physical but also emotional. How do you feel about the progress you've made so far?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Honestly, it's been tough. Some days I feel like I'm taking two steps forward and one step back. But when I look at my hands and see how they're still managing to function, even if it's with some difficulty, it gives me hope.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That must be a relief. Do you ever feel discouraged or want to give up?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, definitely. There are days when I just feel like hiding under the bed because my hands hurt so much. But then I think about all the people who have been supporting me and encouraging me to keep going, and it gives me the strength to keep moving forward.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Good morning, Mr. Johnson! It’s a pleasure to see you today. How are you feeling?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Hi Dr. Lee, thanks for seeing me. I'm doing all right, I guess. A bit frustrated about my arm lately.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Frustrated? Can you tell me more about that? What seems to be the issue with your arm?

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: When you say "frustrated," what kind of activities do you find challenging because of your arm?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Well, it's mainly things like carrying groceries or lifting my grandkids. Sometimes I struggle with opening jars too.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Those are all great examples. Can you tell me more about what happens when you try to lift something heavy? For instance, do you feel any pain or weakness in your arm?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, there's definitely a weakness sensation in my arm and shoulder. It gets worse the heavier the object is. And sometimes it feels like I'm going to pull something.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That sounds uncomfortable. Are there specific situations where you have more trouble? For example, lifting with both arms at once versus just one?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, lifting with both arms is definitely harder for me. Even simple tasks like carrying a full laundry basket or pouring water from the kettle are tough.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: I can imagine that would be very challenging. How do these difficulties make you feel emotionally? Do you ever get anxious or frustrated with your limitations?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Honestly, it does make me a bit anxious at times. It's hard not to compare myself to others who seem more capable, but I try to remind myself of all the things I can still do.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That’s very admirable. Have you talked to anyone about how you're feeling? Do you have any support system or coping strategies that help?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, my wife is great about reminding me of what I can accomplish. And when things get really tough, I remind myself of all the things Timo and I can do together.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That’s wonderful! It sounds like you have a very positive outlook on life. How does your condition affect your daily routine? Are there any tasks or activities that you need to avoid or approach with caution?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, definitely some heavy lifting is out of the question for me now. But I've learned to adapt and find ways to do things that work for my body.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That’s fantastic! It sounds like you're making great progress in learning how to manage your condition. What are your hopes for the future? Are there any specific goals or activities you'd like to be able to accomplish?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, I hope to continue getting stronger so that I can do more things with my grandkids. And maybe even take up some new hobbies that don't require too much heavy lifting.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That’s a great goal! I'm confident we can work together to help you achieve those goals.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** Hi there, thank you for coming in today. How are you feeling?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** I'm okay, a bit frustrated about my current situation.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** Can you tell me more about what's been bothering you lately? Is it related to your hand and arm use or something else?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** It's definitely about my arms. I have trouble performing daily tasks like washing dishes, opening jars, or carrying groceries. It's been this way since the accident.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** Sorry to hear that. Let's focus on those activities for a bit. When you try to perform these tasks, do you feel any pain or discomfort?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** Yes, my arms ache and get tired quickly when I'm doing things like washing dishes or carrying heavy bags. Sometimes it feels like they're going to give out completely.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** That sounds really challenging. Can you think of a specific situation where your hand and arm use was particularly problematic? For example, trying to turn a door handle or throwing something?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** Actually, just yesterday I had trouble opening a jar of pasta sauce. My arms felt weak, and it took me a few tries before I could finally manage it.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** I can imagine how frustrating that must be. Have you noticed any limitations in your range of motion when reaching for things or manipulating objects?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** Yeah, definitely. When I try to reach up high or out to the side, my arm feels stiff and it's hard to move it smoothly. It's like there's a blockage somewhere.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** That must make daily activities take longer than they used to. Are you feeling anxious about this at all? Or is it more of a frustration?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** I'd say it's a mix of both, but mostly frustration. I'm worried that if I don't get help soon, things will only get worse.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** It sounds like we need to work on building up your strength and range of motion in your arms. But first, can you tell me a bit more about what keeps you going? What motivates you to keep pushing through the hard times?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** Well, I guess it's my family and friends. They're always there for me, and they believe I'll get better. Plus, I've got Timo, my dog – he's always happy to see me, no matter how bad a day I'm having.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** That's wonderful! It sounds like you have a good support system in place. And it's great that you're staying positive despite the challenges. We'll work together to get your arms feeling stronger and more capable.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** Sorry to hear that. Can you tell me more about what's going on? Is there something specific bothering you?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** Honestly, it's just the little things. Simple tasks are taking so much effort now, and I feel like I'm losing my independence. Like yesterday, I couldn't even throw a ball for Timo without feeling exhausted.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** That sounds really tough. Can you tell me more about your arm use? Have there been any changes since your accident?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** Yeah...I mean, the injury was a cervical spinal cord injury, so it's mainly affecting my hand and arm function. But what I'm finding is that even simple actions like opening jars or turning doorknobs are becoming impossible for me.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** I see. And how about carrying things? Like grocery bags or your laptop?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** Those are still really challenging. If I try to carry something heavy, my arm feels like it's going to give out on me. It's hard to explain, but it just doesn't feel as strong as it used to.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** That makes sense given the injury you described. Have there been any situations where your lack of function has caused problems or frustrated you?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** Yeah...just everyday stuff like cooking dinner or even getting dressed. These tasks that I used to take for granted are now becoming huge obstacles. It's frustrating and feels like it's taking over my life.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** I can understand why you're feeling overwhelmed. How do these challenges make you feel, both physically and emotionally?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** Physically, I'm just tired all the time. But emotionally...it's hard to explain. It feels like a part of me is missing. Like I've lost who I used to be.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** That's really sad to hear. Have you talked to anyone about these feelings? Maybe family or friends?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** Yeah, they're supportive, but it's just not the same as having someone understand what I'm going through on a daily basis. It feels like nobody gets why this is so hard for me.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** That makes sense. Sometimes having that understanding can feel like it doesn't come from people who haven't experienced something similar themselves. But you're not alone in feeling this way, and we can work together to find ways to make these tasks easier for you.

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** Thank you...just knowing that someone gets it is a big help. I feel like I've been carrying this burden on my own for too long.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** We'll definitely work on getting you the support you need. And remember, every small step forward can be a win. Even if it feels like just a tiny one, it's something to build on.

dialogue.content: ** Yeah, that's still really hard for me. If I reach too far, my shoulder hurts and my elbow feels strained.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** That must be frustrating. How do these challenges make you feel about your progress so far? Are there any moments when it feels like you're slipping backwards or losing ground?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** Honestly, it's a bit demotivating at times. But I've been trying to focus on small victories, like being able to carry groceries for just one trip instead of two.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** That's a great approach! It sounds like you're learning to pace yourself and celebrate your successes along the way. Have you talked to anyone about how these challenges are affecting you emotionally? Do you have any support system in place?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** Yeah, my family is really supportive. And I've been trying to stay positive by reminding myself that it's just a matter of time before things get easier.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** That's wonderful! It's great that you have such a strong support network. Before we end today, what are some goals or aspirations you have for your hand and arm use in the next few weeks? Are there any specific activities you'd like to be able to do more easily?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: ** Yeah, I'd love to be able to carry groceries without getting tired as quickly. And I want to be able to hang clothes on hooks again.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: ** Those are great goals! We can definitely work towards those in our next sessions.

patient_profile.disease: upper limb amputation with prosthetic rehabilitation

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: Good morning, Sarah. Thank you for coming in today. How are you feeling?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Hi, I'm doing alright, I guess. It's been a bit of an adjustment getting used to this new prosthetic.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: I can imagine. It takes time and patience to get comfortable with the changes our body goes through. What was your experience like when you first woke up after the surgery?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Honestly, it was tough. The pain was intense for a while. But my family's support has been amazing. They helped me through the initial recovery.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That means a lot. It can be scary and overwhelming to go through something like that alone. How have your daily activities changed since the surgery?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Well, some things are harder now than they used to be. Cooking, for instance, is a bit of a struggle with one arm. But I've learned to adapt and find ways around it.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That's really great that you're finding ways to adjust. Can you tell me more about the specific difficulties you face with using your prosthetic?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, definitely. Opening jars or bottles is still a challenge. My prosthetic just doesn't have the strength in my wrist area yet.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: I see. And how about tasks like pouring from a kettle or carrying groceries? Do those present any issues for you?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Pouring can be tricky sometimes. The motion of lifting the container with one arm feels unnatural, and it's easy to spill things. Groceries are manageable as long as they're not too heavy.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: I understand. It sounds like there might be some strain on your shoulder or elbow when performing these activities?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, that's right. If I'm not careful, I can feel a bit of discomfort in those areas after doing something strenuous.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That must be frustrating at times. How do you cope with the difficulties you face on a daily basis?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Honestly, it takes me some time to get used to it all again. But my family's support helps a lot. They remind me of how far I've come and that it's okay to take things slow.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That's wonderful. It sounds like having their support is crucial for you. Have you found any ways to manage stress or anxiety related to your prosthetic?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, exercise really helps. Whether it's walking Timo the dog or going to the gym, moving around and staying active keeps my mind off things.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That makes sense. Exercise can be a great way to clear your mind and improve mood. Do you have any plans for the future regarding your prosthetic or any specific goals you'd like to achieve?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.content: Yeah, I'm hoping to get back into hobbies that require more dexterity, like painting. It's something I love doing, but it's been a challenge since the surgery.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.content: That sounds like a great goal to work towards! With practice and patience, I'm sure you'll get there.
